title: S&T Articles | Department Of Science & Technology

items.title: Noise Brings Quantum Surprise from Indian Scientists
items.summary:
- Recent work suggests that *quantum noise* may not always negatively impact *quantum entanglement*.
- Researchers discovered that *intraparticle entanglement* can survive and even thrive in noisy conditions, challenging the assumption that noise is entirely detrimental.
- This study opens new avenues for developing resilient *quantum technologies*, indicating that the quantum realm holds unexpected potential.

items.title: Himalayan Uplift Transformed Kashmir's Ancient Climate
items.summary:
This study unveils how the *Kashmir Valley's* climate shifted from *subtropical* to *Mediterranean* due to tectonic uplift. 
- Fossilized leaves reveal a verdant past and highlight the adaptation mechanisms of ecosystems. 
- Insights gained from climate history can inform predictions for future environmental changes.

items.title: A quantum leap in magnetometry could simplify measurements
items.summary:
- Researchers at Raman Research Institute developed a novel **all-optical quantum magnetometer** based on Raman-Driven Spin Noise Spectroscopy (RDSNS).
- This technique offers high sensitivity with a large dynamic range, enabling measurements in noisy real-world conditions without **magnetic shielding**.
- Potential applications include non-invasive brain scanning, mineral detection, and studying **magnetic fields** in space, advancing India's position in quantum technology.

items.title: Tiny loops in Solar Corona can unveil Sun's hidden explosive secrets | Department Of Science
Color-Shifting Materials for Wearable Tech
items.summary:
This breakthrough involves *structural coloration* to create *tunable color-shifting materials*:
- Researchers at CeNS used *polystyrene nanospheres* that self-assemble into a close-packed layer, enabling precise control over reflected light colors.
- By altering the size of these spheres and their arrangement, they achieved *durable and vibrant colors* suitable for various applications like sensors and eco-friendly paints.
- Their method is scalable and cost-effective, enhancing the potential for *custom-designed optical materials* without harmful dyes.

items.title: New Pocket-Sized Sensor Detects Toxic SO2 Gas
items.summary:
- A new low-cost sensor detects *toxic sulfur dioxide* (SO<sub>2</sub>) gas, which can cause serious health issues, even at low concentrations. 
- Developed by scientists at CeNS, the sensor combines *nickel oxide* and *neodymium nickelate* to detect SO<sub>2</sub> down to 320 ppb, surpassing many commercial options. 
- The compact, user-friendly prototype features a *threshold-based alert system*, making it suitable for various environments needing real-time air quality monitoring.

items.title: Indian Scientists Engineer Supercharged Green Energy Material
items.summary:
- Indian scientists have developed a *next-generation energy storage material* that significantly enhances supercapacitor performance.
- By doping silver niobate with *lanthanum*, they achieved 100% efficiency and improved energy retention to 118%.
- This innovation paves the way for compact, high-efficiency storage devices for various applications, from *portable electronics* to *renewable energy systems*.

items.title: Novel Duality in Altermagnets Could Transform Electronics
items.summary:
- Researchers discovered unique properties in *altermagnets*, especially chromium antimonide (*CrSb*), which could revolutionize electronic device design. 
- CrSb exhibits *direction-dependent conduction polarity (DDCP)*, allowing it to behave as both p-type and n-type material, simplifying device architectures. 
- This discovery could lead to more *compact, efficient*, and *eco-friendly electronics*, crucial for next-generation spintronic devices.

items.title: Teak Leaf: A Natural Biodegradable Laser Shield
items.summary:
- *Teak leaf extract* offers protection against harmful laser rays, ideal for sensitive applications in medicine and military. 
- Scientists discovered its *nonlinear optical properties*, making it a viable, eco-friendly alternative to synthetic materials. 
- This innovation could lead to **sustainable laser protection equipment** like safety goggles and coatings, contributing to greener technologies.

items.title: New CRISPR Technology Helps Plants Combat Stress
items.summary:
- A novel CRISPR tool enables plants to defend themselves from *heat* and *disease* by acting as a gene switch that activates during stress.
- Scientists utilized a protein from tomatoes, allowing the dCas9 switch to turn on essential defense genes when needed.
- This advancement could revolutionize crop resilience, benefiting not just tomatoes but also potatoes, *eggplants*, and other vital food crops.

items.title: Technology: The Engine of India's Growth
items.author: Dr. Jitendra Singh
items.summary:
- Dr. Jitendra Singh highlights the last 11 years as pivotal for transforming *technology* into a key driver of India's economic growth.
- Emphasizing innovative reforms under PM Modi, Singh notes significant advancements across *agriculture*, *biotech*, and *climate sciences*.
- India is positioned as a *global leader* in biotechnology with initiatives like the BioE3 Policy fostering an environment ripe for **innovation**.

items.title: Innovative Water Purification Using Sunlight and AI
items.summary:
- Researchers developed a new water filter that utilizes *sunlight*, *vibrations*, and **AI** to effectively degrade pollutants.
- The innovative system surpasses traditional methods by removing up to **98.9%** of harmful dyes from wastewater and is biodegradable and eco-friendly.
- It employs *machine learning* to optimize performance, making it suitable for various industries and remote communities.

items.title: India's Solar Leap to Produce Green Hydrogen
items.summary:
- Researchers have developed a *next-generation device* that produces green hydrogen using *solar energy* and *earth-abundant materials*.
- This device boasts high efficiency, enhanced durability, and a significant reduction in reliance on expensive resources, achieving impressive performance metrics.
- The technology, detailed in the *Journal of Materials Chemistry A*, aims to advance *affordable, large-scale solar-to-hydrogen energy systems*.

items.title: "The hidden healers in poisonous plants", A Research Study by IASST, Guwahati | Department Of Science
New Stellar Chemistry Discovered in Star A980
items.summary:
- Scientists discovered *germanium* in the rare *Extreme Helium* star A980, an element previously unseen in such stars.
- Germanium was found to be *eight times more abundant* in A980 than in the Sun, indicating unique stellar processes.
- The discovery sheds light on stellar evolution, suggesting A980's history might involve mergers of white dwarfs or hybrid stars known as *Thorne-Żytkow Objects*.

items.title: A 24-million-year-old secret unearthed
items.summary:
- Scientists discovered ancient *fossil leaves* in Northeast India that reshape the history of *biodiversity* in the region.
- The fossils, belonging to the *Nothopegia* genus, reveal a once warm, humid climate similar to that of the *Western Ghats*, now a biodiversity hotspot.
- This research highlights how *climate change* historically affected plant species' distribution and serves as a vital lesson for current *biodiversity conservation strategies*.

items.title: A simplified method to synthesize nano-cups that can blaze the cancer with heat
items.summary:
- Researchers developed a *one-step colloidal synthesis method* for nanoparticles with *nano-cup morphology* that assists in *photothermal therapy* for cancer treatment.
- This approach replaces traditional multi-step methods and toxic agents with a *biocompatible metal-organic framework* and mild reducing agents, showing *high therapeutic efficacy* in destroying metastatic breast tumors.
- Future applications include *chemo-photothermal therapy* and advancements in *SERS biosensing*, enhancing precision in oncological treatments.

items.title: Climate Change Observations from Himalayan Regions
items.summary:
- Global *atmospheric science experts* met in Nainital to discuss *greenhouse gas changes* and FTIR observations from the Himalayas.
- The meeting emphasized the critical role of *Himalayan observations* for understanding climate change due to limited ground data and ineffective space-based observations.
- Approximately *70 participants*, including 47 international experts, attended the 5-day conference hosted by ARIES.
